comment:
Dear Dr. Neil Crickmore, 
We isolated a Bacillus thuringiensis strain named as Bt 29-5 toxic to Plutella xylostella from a soil sample, which exhibited spore-crystal association (SCA) phenotype. When analyzed by SDS-PAGE，there has a main protein band about 70 kDa. This protein band was excised and analyzed by mass spectrometry analysis. While searching the database derived from the genomic sequence of Bt 29-5, we identified this protein as this submitted protein BIP-29A exhibiting about 25% sequence similarity with the known proteins.  The gene for BIP-29A was cloned into acrystalliferous Bt strain, it was expressed and deposited as free crystal composed as the protein BIP-29A, which was toxic to P. xylostella. Considering its toxicity to P. xylostella and low sequence similarity to known proteins, we would like to submit this protein to BPPRC for nomenclature. Thank you very much for your work!

Sincerely yours,
Yunjun Sun
admin_comments:
From: Neil Crickmore 
Sent: 18 November 2020 11:26
To: 孙运军 <sunyj@hunnu.edu.cn>
Subject: RE: nomenclature of a pesticidal protein

Yunjun, I have just had a quick look at your protein. As you say it has very little similarity to other pesticidal proteins (or indeed any other proteins in Genbank). Because of this we need to be really sure that it is a proper toxin. Could you therefore clarify the following points:

1)	Can you confirm the mass-spec result. Are you saying that the fingerprint of the 70kDa protein from Bt 29-5 matches the deduced sequence from BIP-29A? How much coverage was there?
2)	When you expressed BIP-29A in Bt was the expressed protein the same size as that from the Bt29-5 strain?
3)	When you say that the recombinant protein was toxic to P.xylostella could you give a few more details about the assay. How much protein was used? How much mortality was observed etc.

Neil

comment:
92.7.0% identity to Cry2Ab1.
We ask not to make the sequence publicly available while publications or intellectual property are being prepared, please hold sequences securely until publication
admin_comments:
From: Etan Ben-dov <etn@bgu.ac.il> 
Sent: 05 December 2020 17:20
To: Neil Crickmore <n.crickmore@sussex.ac.uk>
Cc: Arieh Zaritsky (ariehzar@gmail.com) <ariehzar@gmail.com>; Dana Ment <danam@volcani.agri.gov.il>
Subject: RE: New pesticidal proteins

Hi Neil,
Thank you for assignment our sequences…
I will check the upstream sequences of the MW238543 and MW238544 for a ribosome binding site and get back to you soon.
We will clone the MW238541 (cry1Bk1) gene to recombinant bacteria for confirmation toxic activity but it will take some time (maybe a few months). 
Eitan

From: Neil Crickmore <n.crickmore@sussex.ac.uk> 
Sent: Friday, December 4, 2020 1:00 PM
To: איתן בן דוב <etn@bgu.ac.il>
Subject: RE: New pesticidal proteins

Eitan, I have gone through your sequences in more detail now.

MW238546: I can enter this into the nomenclature as Cry1Ia42
MW238547: Cry2Ab41
MW238548: Cry9Ea12
MW238549: Vip3Aa79
MW238541: This one looks like a novel Cry1B and would enter the nomenclature as Cry1Bk1, however in order to do this we need confirmation of activity. In you submission you claimed toxicity against Thaumatotibia leucotreta. Can you confirm that this activity was seen with the recombinant protein and not just the strain encoding this protein?
MW238542: Cry1Ia43
MW238543: I suspect a sequencing error here, this looks like a Cry2Ab. If an extra A were present in that run of As at the beginning of your sequence then it would be a perfect match to Cry2Ab. If the sequence you gave were to be expressed there should be a ribosome binding start just upstream from your predicted start codon. Is there one?
MW238544: Vip3Aa80 – although I suspect that the wrong start codon has been picked. Again can you check the relative location of the rbs.
MW238545: Vpb1Ac2
